entry.title: Re: Add screen text field dynamically
entry.content:
Hi Geoff, you can try also the following way:

  • create a dynpro screen with a custom control
  • instantiate custom control object of class CL_GUI_CUSTOM_CONTAINER (for example in PBO)
  • (optionally) create a splitter object (class CL_GUI_SPLITTER_CONTAINER) if you need several containers for your objects
  • create dynamically your screen objects in the corresponding containers. In your case it could be class CL_GUI_INPUT_FIELD. You can find further suitable classes as subclasses of CL_GUI_CONTROL.

Last time I checked this approach, it had several limitations and was not really convenient for my solution, although it could be suitable for some of your use cases.

entry.title: How to deal with 200 responsibility groups limitation in Onboarding General Settings
entry.content:
Hi, 

We have a limitation in the creation of Responsible Groups; we need to create 527 groups to distribute the Final Review task.

First, we are creating a lookup table, but in order to associate employees with the final review task, we would need to create the table based on ONB2ResponsibilityConfig and assign those groups to each value in the table. Therefore, the table is not really useful, because we are doing the same work we still need to create 527 groups to assign them to each table entry so that the system knows which employees to assign to the tasks.

On the other hand, we performed a test, and if I include more than 200 people in a group, the task is only assigned to the first 200.

However, I don‚Äôt understand the limitation I‚Äôm facing the problem is that when I try to assign a dynamic group to a responsible group, it doesn‚Äôt appear even though it has been created.

Thanks in advance. Daniel

Is there any way to bring back the configuration so we can perform maintenance and updates?

entry.title: Re: How to extract BOM Explosion and Configuration detail...
entry.content:
Good day @cirill0d 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Variant Configuration, Advanced Variant Configuration, Generation of Classification and Variant Configuration Views, Integrating SAP Datasphere, Integrating CDS Views Using SAP Datasphere, Custom CDS Views, View Browser

The summary to your questions is, in public cloud, you cannot access tables like CUOB, CUKN, or IBIN, as variant configuration data is generated at runtime by the Advanced Variant Configuration engine. You can adhere to the clean-core way to extract configuration and BOM explosion data by using the released AVC CDS views: I_ConfigurationInstance, I_ProductConfigurationBOMItem and I_ProductVariantConfigurationCharacteristic.  These have similar details to what you see in VA03.

If you are considering automation, you can also consume API_PRODUTCONFIGURTION_SRV through SAP BTP and feed the results into SAP Datasphere.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Project financial and cost planning on S/4HANA Public Cloud.
entry.content:
Hello, dear gurus.
A company dedicated to constructing, renovating, and renting offices wants to implement S/4HANA Public Cloud. However, it needs to simulate predictive scenarios for changes in material costs and economic factors, such as inflation and tariffs, for both individual projects and portfolios. Does S/4HANA Public Cloud offer this functionality? If not, what additional solution would be most appropriate? SAC Planning? PAPM? Which tool is more feasible and simple to integrate and use with S/4HANA Public Cloud?

The company does not want to load the plan from Excel. Rather, they want a tool to plan which investments are appropriate and which are not.

@Luana_Lovison 

@Elton SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Finance

entry.title: BTP trial account
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I want to share my strong disappointment regarding the recent changes to the SAP BTP Free Tier/Trial accounts. These restrictions are making it very difficult for new developers and learners to use the platform.

 

1. The Deployment Block

 

The biggest issue is stopping the deployment of apps in BTP for free.

  • BTP is a platform for running apps. If we can't deploy our prototypes and completed tutorials, we can't truly learn how the platform works end-to-end.

  • This is a major setback for anyone trying to get hands-on experience and makes BTP far less accessible for the community.

 

2. Request to Restore Memory

 

I also want to request a return to the older, more generous limits:

  • Please restore the allowed memory limit to 4GB. The current reduced memory quota is too small for many real-world development examples and makes the platform feel unusable for meaningful learning.

I urge the SAP BTP team to reconsider these decisions.

A truly usable free tier is an investment in the future of the BTP developer community. Please restore the ability to deploy applications and give us back the 4GB of memory.

Thank you for listening.

entry.title: Help with Retrieving Modified Condition Values in IF_EX_ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST~CHECK Method
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

I‚Äôm working on customizing the procurement process and I‚Äôm facing an issue when trying to retrieve the modified condition values from the screen in the IF_EX_ME_PROCESS_PO_CUST~CHECK method.

Issue:

I want to get the condition values of the line items after they have been modified on the screen in ME22N. However, when I call get_conditions in the CHECK method, the values I retrieve are still the original (pre-modification) values, not the updated ones.

METHOD if_ex_me_process_po_cust~check.
  DATA: ls_header TYPE mepoheader,
        lo_data_item TYPE REF TO if_purchase_order_item_mm,
        lt_conditions TYPE mmpur_tkomv,
        ls_condition TYPE komv.  

  IF im_header IS NOT INITIAL.
    CALL METHOD im_header->get_items RECEIVING re_items = lt_items_data.
  
    LOOP AT lt_items_data INTO ls_items_data.
      lo_data_item = ls_items_data-item.
      
      CALL METHOD lo_data_item->get_conditions
        IMPORTING
          ex_conditions = lt_conditions.
    ENDLOOP.

  ENDIF.
ENDMETHOD.

entry.title: Re: SAP S4HANA Public Cloud - how to post FIFO valuation...
entry.content:
Hello @rekafulop 

Thank you for your question.

Have you had a look at the prerequisites defined for the process? Here are some references to guide you.

FIFO Valuation, Inventory Valuation, Valuation Alternatives

The error about the Journal Entries not being available often refers to the valuation differences being cancelled out at the ledger level, or the job being executed in simulation mode without account mapping being active. When you run FIFO Valuation Delta Posting in public cloud, the system calculates revaluation differences between book value and FIFO cost. My advice is to check your system and ensure that:

The job run mode is Execute Posting, Account determination for Valuation Alternative is complete and the posting period is open. Once confirmed the next Delta Posting run will generate a Journal Entry with the adjustment value.

The total value (EUR 626,149) shown represents the gross delta and not necessarily the final posting amount unless a net adjustment exists per value area.

 

Below is a detailed FIFO valuation process.

Open the Adjust Balance Sheet Accounts ‚Äì Delta Posting -->

Show Parameters/Job Log, enter details and run. Ensure Test Run-Nothing will be posted is not checked.

System creates a job and completes it with no errors.

Then search for Execute FIFO Valuation

Ensure update Result details are ticked.

Go back to Adjust Balance Sheet Accounts ‚Äì Delta Posting --> keep same parameters but remove the material number and run for all materials.

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: SAP BDC - Enhance a BW Data product with SAP Databricks - Part II
entry.content:
This two-part blog series ‚Äî created by the Italian Solution Advisory team ‚Äî provides an end-to-end guide for SAP BW customers looking to modernize their analytics landscape using SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC).

The following diagram summarizes the overall workflow of the activities:

The first chapter of the series is structured as follows:

1 - Create a data product subscription to a custom BW infoprovider and replicate the data into SAP BDC
2 - Govern the custom data product access by data catalog sharing

The second one will be available shortly with this content:

3 - Derive insights by leveraging SAP Databricks ML capabilities
4 - Incorporate results to support business decisions

Our goal is to demonstrate how SAP BDC can accelerate BW modernization ‚Äî delivering a state-of-the-art, end-to-end data management and analytics experience.

3 - Derive insights by leveraging SAP Databricks ML capabilities

Use-case

Anomaly detection in accounting data is a routine of an auditor that reviews financial statements. In General ledger (GL) data, business transactions are represented as journal entries. An atomic record that belongs to a unique journal entry is a transaction with an account type and corresponding attributes including among others a monetary amount with debit-credit sign. Anomalies in this data include amongst others, incorrect account type combinations, wrong corresponding monetary amount, and abnormal amount proportions for the standard account patterns. Such deviations from standards in GL data may account for mistakes or intentional fraudulent activities. Experienced auditors perform assessment of financial statements based on their professional knowledge by manually ‚Äôwalking through‚Äô sampled GL data.  It is a laborious and time intensive task. 

Data Product generated from SAP BW/4HANA in previous steps contains GL data extract, thus we decided to implement a machine learning model to illustrate a possibility to facilitate auditors' tasks and suggest potentially anomalous journal entries.  

For this purpose, Isolation Forest model for Anomaly detection was chosen. 

Isolation forest is a type of tree-based ensemble algorithm similar to random forest. The algorithm is designed to assume that inliers in a given set of observations are harder to isolate than outliers (anomalous observations). At a high level, a non-anomalous point, that is a regular journal entry, would live deeper in a decision tree as they are harder to isolate, and the inverse is true for an anomalous point. This algorithm can be trained on a label-less set of observations and subsequently used to predict anomalous records in previously unseen data. 

Data exploration 

From the Unity Catalog in Delta Shares Received section under data product s4_figl4_raw_data you can get familiar with the content of the data set. It is possible to check column types and to examine Sample data. This is a preliminary phase to get to know the data set. 

We continued learning about the data within Databricks Notbook using Python.  Another possible way is to use SQL Explorer. For this purpose, we created a separate folder named Anomaly detection GL to keep all related artifacts in one place.  

Notebook Anomaly detection IF on GL data contains Python code which was executed for data loading, data exploration, features engineering, model building, and saving the result.  After importing all the necessary Python libraries, we read data set into Spark Data Frame. 

We checked the general statistics of the data frame. We noticed that some numerical features like DEBIT_DC and CREDIT_LC3 have all 0 values. They could be good candidates to be eliminated from model training. 

In the exploration phase, we discovered that our dataset has very few data points before November 2024 as can be seen in the graph below. At this point, we decided to work only with the newer data, the last six months, as highly likely older data is not fully available, and results wouldn‚Äôt be relevant. 

Features engineering 

In the dataset, there are very few numeric features, only 8 of them referring to Credit and Debit amounts. All others are categorical features for which it is useful to determine their cardinality to decide if to keep them in the dataset or not. 

Features with cardinality 1, having the same value for all data points, provide no useful information for predictive modeling or anomaly detection because they do not differentiate between data points. Removing these features reduces the dimensionality of the dataset, which can simplify the model and potentially improve its performance and interpretability. In this exercise, we deleted features with cardinality 1. 

Most machine learning algorithms require numerical input to perform their calculations. Categorical data needs to be transformed into a numerical format for these algorithms to use effectively. One-hot encoding provides a straightforward way to achieve this transformation, ensuring that categorical variables can be integrated into machine learning models and it was applied here. 

Model building 

In this exercise, we worked with MLflow. 

MLflow is an open-source platform designed to simplify the end-to-end machine learning lifecycle. It provides a comprehensive set of tools and frameworks to manage and track the end-to-end ML development process, including experimentation, reproducibility, deployment, and collaboration. It was developed by Databricks and consists of four main components: 

  • MLflow Tracking: Logs and queries experiments, including code, data, and configuration. 
  • MLflow Projects: Packages ML code in a reusable, reproducible form. 
  • MLflow Models: Manages and deploys models from various ML libraries. 
  • MLflow Registry: A central repository to manage the full lifecycle of MLflow models, including versioning and annotations.  

To create model, we used Python library sklearn.ensemble which contains ensemble-based methods for classification, regression and anomaly detection. We passed following parameters to the Isolation Forest method: 

Number of estimators: n_estimators refers to the number of base estimators or trees in the ensemble, i.e., the number of trees that will get built in the forest.  

Max samples: max_samples is the number of samples to be drawn to train each base estimator.  

Contamination: This is a parameter that the algorithm is quite sensitive to and it refers to the expected proportion of outliers in the dataset. This is used when fitting to define the threshold on the scores of the samples.. 

MLflow enables to record the hyperparametrs used to train Isolation Forest model via mlflwo.log_param() function. 

We plotted the distribution of anomaly scores. 

  • Two distinct groups: For datasets with clear anomalies, the histogram will often show two main groupings of scores: a dense cluster around a higher value (the normal instances) and a smaller, distinct cluster of low, negative scores (the anomalies). 
  • Decision boundary: The vertical dashed red line in the histogram represents the model.threshold_. Points to the left of this line are classified as anomalies, while points to the right are classified as normal. 

In our cases, two clusters are not distinctly different; the score distributions overlap, making it harder to pick a single clear cutoff point. The contamination parameter was used to force the model to classify 1% of the data as outliers. 

Given that Isolation Forest is an unsupervised algorithm, we don‚Äôt know the ground truth; we saved mean anomaly score as a metric. Also, we logged the model and histogram as artifacts. 

Next, we assigned anomaly score and marked each data point as anomalous, value ‚Äì1 or regular, value 1. 

Finally, we saved the result into the table gl_anomalies_prediction, in default schema in our workspace. 

Table became visible inside of the Catalog, under the workspace schema default in Tables section. 

Remark 1: To be able to expose the table as a Data Product in BDC, the table has to have a primary key. 

In this case, we found columns which uniquely identify each data point and created a composite primary key from following columns: ODQ_TSN,  ODQ_UNITNO, ODQ_RECORDNO. 

Remark 2: The information that was logged while running the model is available in the Experiments section under Anomaly detection IF on GL data/ML Model. 

For each run we can see mean anomaly score and hyperparameter values. 

If we drill down, we can get all the artifacts related to the given run. 

Remark 3: There are many opportunities to work further in this use case, for example: 

  • As we don‚Äôt have ground truth labels, we could involve domain experts to review the detected anomalies and assess their relevance and importance.  
  • Generate synthetic anomalies by introducing known outliers into the dataset and evaluate the model's performance on detecting these synthetic anomalies. 
  • Apply clustering techniques to group similar anomalies together, which can help in understanding common patterns or types of anomalies. 
  • Adjust the hyperparameters of the Isolation Forest (e.g., `n_estimators`, `max_samples`, `contamination`) to improve performance. 

Create a Delta Share 

To be able to use the result from our analysis, it is necessary to expose the Delta Share to the workspace.  

The prerequisite is that the user has the necessary privileges to be able to perform the task.  The privileges requested are CREATE CATALOG, CREATE SHARE, SET SHARE PERMISSION, USE PROVIDER, USE RECIPIENT, and USE SHARE.  How to add the privileges is described in the following link  Adding Privileges into SAP Databricks | SAP Help Portal. 

That can be done with the Catalog, choosing the Manage (Gear icon) button and, from the dropdown menu, select Delta sharing. 

Inside of Delta Share you‚Äôll find a button Share data.

Clicking on Share data you can Crate share by providing following info: 

  1.  In the Share name field, enter a share name, in our case anomaly_detection_gl and choose Save and continue. The Description field is optional. 
  2. Add data assets: Select one or more schemas, which includes all the tables in the schema, or one or more individual tables. Choose Save and continue. 

  1. Add notebooks: (Optional) Specify the Storage location. Choose Save and continue. 
  1. Add recipients: In the Recipient field, from the dropdown menu, select sap-business-data-cloud. Choose Share data. 

Publishing the Delta Share as Data Product to BDC 

To complete this step, it is necessary to use Python SDK. In the new notebook, which we called Sharing Anomaly Detection on GL data to BDC, we installed the library sap-bdc-connect-sdk. 

In the next step, we created the share in sap-bdc-connect-sdk. A share is a mechanism for distributing and accessing data across different systems. Creating a share involves including specific attributes, such as @openResourceDiscoveryV1, in the request body, aligning with the Open Resource Discovery protocol. This procedure ensures that the share is properly structured and described according to specified standards, facilitating effective data sharing and management. 

Then, we created CSN share. The CSN serves as a standardized format for configuring and describing shares within a network. It ensures accuracy and compliance with the CSN interoperability specifications, facilitating consistent and effective share of configuration across systems. 

Finaly, we published the data product using the following Python code.

4 - Incorporate results to support business decisions

The new enhanced Dataproduct, output of the ML calculation is now visibile in SAP BDC: 

In SAP Datasphere we can then build a new Analytical model to support insights. The prerequisite is to install the new data product in one of our spaces from SAP Datasphere catalog. 

After the successful data product installation, data is ready to be consumed. For this purpose, we built a View GV_ANOMALIES_PREDICTION  to serve as a Fact table. From Data Builder choose New Graphical Model. 

We used table gl_anomalies_prediction without any filters, defining Semantic Usage as Fact and configuring all monetary fields, credits and debits as measures with SUM aggregation. Anomaly score and anomaly (values ‚Äì1 and 1) are considered as attributes as they should be used as filters for exposing anomalous journal enteries. 

On top of the fact, we built an Analytic Model, AM_ANOMALIES_PREDICTION to use it in SAP Analytics Cloud. 

 

 Finally, Analytic model was used in the Story builder to present to end user records which are identified by the model as potentially anomalous (anomaly attribute is equal to -1). 

‚Äã

Kind regards, Bjoern

entry.title: Do you know how to implement SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, Sourcing and Procurement?
entry.content:
I recommend to access our Implementing SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, Sourcing and Procurement learning journey.

Learning outcome
By the end of this learning journey, you will be able to:

  • Explain and execute core implementation project tasks to deploy, adopt, and extend SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. This includes setting up systems, configuring business processes with Configuration, working with the SAP Fiori Launchpad, and testing configured processes with automation.
  • Explain and execute the sourcing and procurement-specific solution. processes in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition. This includes fundamental topics such as master data, basic configuration, workflows from a procurement perspective, and core procurement solution processes such as requisitioning, purchasing, sourcing, and contract management.

Goals

  • Get started with SAP: Building the basics
  • Develop your experience: Skill deepening learning
  • Excel in your expertise: Advanced specialization learning

Please post your question related to the digital learning journey in  the Q&A area.

I appreciate your feedback and we will make sure to continue sharing interesting topics.

Kind regards, Katrin

entry.title: TRM - Managing Structured Loan with Variable Principal Payments
entry.content:
I‚Äôm looking into how other SAP TRM experts have handled a specific loan scenario and would appreciate your insights.

Overview: We‚Äôre dealing with a loan that has a structured payment schedule for both principal and interest. While the payment frequency is fixed, the principal payment amounts vary with each installment.

Question: Can this scenario still be managed using 55A (Interest Rate Instrument), or is it necessary to use 54A (Cash Flow Transactions) instead?

Current Approach: My proposed solution is to:

  • Create a custom flow type/condition type to mimic installment payments (e.g., using flow type 1130).
  • Set the condition category to 90 (Other Flow/Condition).
  • Allow users to input variable principal payments manually in Other Flows
  • Set the repayment structure to ‚ÄúFinal Repayment‚Äù.

Concerns:

  1. Are there any known issues with this approach?
  2. How can I ensure that other flows reducing the principal are accurately reflected in:
    • The interest calculation, and
    • The final repayment amount/ Loan?

Any feedback or alternative method would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Additional quantity in warehouse task for production staging
entry.content:
Hello Experts!

Our client is using EWM for production staging. Here is the process we have designed:

- From production order we initiate material staging

- Then from the app 'Process Posting Change Item' we create the warehouse task with destination as the production supply area.

- We confirm the warehouse task upon physically moving the components.

- We consume the components using backflushing (CO11N screen)

Now the ask from our client is - to add some buffer quantity when we are staging in case the line operator needs more. It is the nature of the production that they often need some extra quantity.

Now the problem is, system does not allow us to increase quantity in WT. Also, we cannot increase the quantity in BOM as it will force us to backflush the total quantity.

 Is there a way we can add some tolerance (like always have 10% extra quantity) to the Warehouse Task? Say, the production order needs 10 units, but in WT system proposes 11 units?

If you feel this could be addressed by a different process, let me know. I am open to ideas/leading practices.

Thank you

Snigdhodeep

EWM - Goods Movement #EWM - Production Staging #EWM - Warehouse Tasks

entry.title: S/4+EWM - API call for planned Handling Units (HUs)
entry.content:
Hi everyone, I'm currently working with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition (2023) with SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and I'm trying to automate a delivery from production process using APIs only.

My goal is to create an Inbound Delivery and the corresponding planned Handlings Units. I'm following the documentation provided here: Operations for Handling Unit API

I've been trying for days to create a planned HU via API but it doesn't work. The only thing that worked were stock HUs üòê

Is there any way to create planned Handling Units for a given Product through an API? If yes, could someone please share an examples payload?

I‚Äôd really appreciate any tips or suggestions. Thanks a lot!
Bart

entry.title: Re: EWM diff. analyzer: correct. of Q2 stock not triggeri...
entry.content:
Please see SAP-KBA "3608937 - Unable to enter Reason for Movement in Physical Inventory - SAP for Me" ...

Extract :
"Cause
In the EWM standard solution where postings from the Difference Analyzer are performed using movement type 711/712, the reason is hard coded as 'Inventory'. Hence there is no provision for the user to enter a custom reason for movement.

Resolution
The BAdI /SCWM/EX_ERP_GOODSMVT_EXT can be used to change the material document to be posted in ERP by providing a customer-specific movement type and Reason for Movement."

Hope this helps

Kind regards

Nic T.

entry.title: BI2025: Side-by-Side Migration
entry.content:
This is follow up on the migration topic to BI2025 from my blog: BI2025: Side-by-Side Migration vs. In-Place Update

Lets discuss what activities need to be planned to move to BI2025 if you choose side-by-side approach and also what kind of resource could be helpful to plan the migration/update.

Migrating from SAP BusinessObjects BI4.3 to BI2025 involves several strategic steps to ensure a smooth transition the newer platform. Based on resource availability and internal processes following major activities could be considered:

  1. Pre-Migration Planning
  2. Content Cleanup
  3. BIP 2025 deployment
  4. Content promotion
  5. Testing and Validation
  6. Training & Documentation

We will now take a detailed look at these activities.

1 . Pre-Migration Planning

  • Conduct a full assessment of your current BI 4.3 environment, including hardware, software, and system architecture. Consider to plan  following tasks:

1. 1 Environment Inventory

  • Task: Document the hardware and software components of your current BI 4.3 environment.
  • Details:
    • List all servers and their specifications (CPU, RAM, OS Version).
    • List all installed software middlwares and  databases, SDK-Applications.
    • Review all integration points with other systems, user authentification methods and used SSOs
    • Document network configurations, including firewalls, load balancers, and network topology.

You can use SAP BI Platform Support Tool to get overview of current used applications, number of reports, middlware and data base versions. Please refer to KBA 2407767 - SAP BI Platform Support Tool

Also Auditing reports are quite helpful to get overview of current system and content usage.

Please refer to following resources: SAP KBA 2456458 - Auditing in SAP BI Platform 4.x  and additional blogs about auditing, with sample reports:

  • Auditing Solution Update for SAP BusinessObjects BI Platform 4.3 +

Verify the compatibility of the new version with your current operating systems, databases, and SDK-application. Please check latest  PAM version KBA 1338845 - How to find Product Availability Matrix (PAM) / Supported Platforms Documentation for SAP BusinessObjects products?

Review features which are removed or deprecated in BI2025 and plan migration to alternative solutions.

  • Please see KBA 3560025 - Which products and features are removed in SAP BusinessObjects BI platform 2025.
  • 3582341 - FAQ on SAP BusinessObjects 2025 [BI 2025]
  • For deprecated features

Component

Go to solution

Blog

Lumira Discovery

SAP Analytics Cloud - Web Intelligence

Accelerate your move from SAP Lumira Designer to SAP Analytics Cloud

Crystal Reports for Enterprise

Crystal Reports - Web Intelligence

Moving from Crystal Reports for Enterprise to Crystal Reports

Analysis for OLAP

SAP Analytics Cloud

SAP-BusinessObjects Analysis Edition For Olap Alternatives

Live Office

SAP Analysis for Microsoft Office

Web Intelligence Document OData Access (4.3 SP2)

SAP BusinessObjects Live Office Alternatives

SAP BusinessObjects Mobile

Web browser on mobile devices

Web Intelligence Document eXtract (WIDX)

SAP BusinessObjects Mobile alternatives

Universe Design Tool (and .unv)

Information Design Tool (and .unx)

Unv is dead long live-unx 

Multi-source universes and associated connectivity

Data blending in Web Intelligence or at the DB level

BusinessObjects Multi source Universes Alternatives

Subversion as a bundled Version Management repository

Git or Github integration

SAP KBAs: 3581196 and 3335429 

1.2 User and License Assessment

  • Task: Evaluate the user base and current used licenses
  • Details:
    • List all active and inactive users.
    • Document the types of licenses currently in use.
    • Consider to create new licence keys for BI2025
  • KBAs:
    • 2251998 - How to generate license keys for SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence
    • 2282189 - New license keys required for 4.3/2025(and later)

Task 1.3 Backup and Recovery Assessment

  • Task: Assess the current backup and recovery procedures.
  • Details:
    • Check current backup methodology.
    • You will need a backup of Central Management Server (CMS) database & File Store, any Web Appserver configuration files, Webapps and customizations, and if SAP BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform is on Virtual Machine, then it is advisable to take a snapshot of the machine.
    • Verify the integrity and restorability of backups.
    • Ensure that backups cover all critical data and configurations before performing update
  • KBAs:
    • 2306146 - Disaster recovery backup and restore best practices for restoring
    • 1275068 - Backup & Restore XI 3.1 / BI 4.x from one environment to another [video]

2. Content Cleanup

It would be good idea to perform some system clean up activities to reduce system foot print in CMS DB and FRS and also get rid off the obsolete or unused objects.

2.1. Obsolete Reporting Tools

  • Task: Review content used in BI4.3.
  • Details:
    • Based on analysis performed earlier define the strategy for outdated reporting tools/content (such as legacy Crystal Reports and Analysis for OLAP), decide whether to replace them with new solutions or remove them.
    • Archive obsolete content, if necessary. You can use LCM_BIAR files to create back-ups.
    • Remove or consolidate reports that are redundant or unused to streamline the migration process. Refer to SAP KBA 2464908 - SAP BI Promotion Management Best Practices [LCM]

Task 2.2 Consistency check

  • Task: Verify object consitency between the FRS and CMS database.
  • Details:
    • The inconsistencies can occur after disaster recovery, a network failure during a database write, content insert or update.
    • Run a Repository Diagnostics Scan (Reposcan) on Source (and on Target, after migration). Use both CMS and FRS: Scan & Repair options in the Source Environment.
  • KBAs and RDT Resources:
    • How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool
    • 1689163 - How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool (aka reposcan) in BI 4.x - for WINDOWS
    • 1752397 - How to use the Repository Diagnostic Tool (aka reposcan) in BI 4.x - for Unix / Linux,
    • 2306600 - How to resolve "The object has a missing or invalid Submitter Object ID." inconsistency after a CMS database migration
    • 1695971 - Repository Diagnostic Tool (reposcan) shows more file inconsistencies after the repair
    • 1267338 - How to use Repository Diagnostic Tool (reposcan)

3. BIP 2025 deployment

Task 3.1: Hardware and Network Preparation

  • Task: Ensure that your infrastructure meets BI2025‚Äôs technical requirements including hardware, operating system, and networking specifications.
  • Details:
    • Consider to check BI2025 PAM to verify if all prerequisites met
    • Align on network requirements and firewalls rules requierd for new enviroment. Please refer to KBA 2276646 - Firewall considerations for BusinessObjects Business Intelligence Platform 4.x (Servers and Clients)

For example, in PAM you can find information on supported in BI2025 operating systems and web application servers:

 

Provider NameNameMinimum Supported versionLatest
certified version		Supported
since		Notes

 

Tomcat9.x9.xBI 2025

Certified for SAP Machine (Java 17). As free open-source third-party web application server, SAP recommends you contact a qualified third-party vendor or consultant for performance tuning, security related issues and load balancer configurations (see SAP KBA 2280098). Please check KBA 2112338 for bundled tomcat and JVM version

BI 2025 is only supported on Windows and Linux operating systems and the Solaris and AIX support is removed.
With the GA release, BI 2025 is only supported on Tomcat Application Server, more importantly SAP NetWeaver application server support is removed. And other application servers certification is planned for future.

Next important topic is also BIP Add-ons.

‚ÄãBI2025 requires new Lumira Add-on - SAP Lumira Designer 2025, which is currently planned to be released in Q12026:
 
Analysis for Office Add-On.
‚ÄãBI2025 requires at least Analysis for Office SP26 installer.
‚ÄãFurthermore, additional improvement planned for AO 2.8 SP28  related to the SNC and the OpenID usage for the BIP Logon:
  • 3631157 - AO: BIP Logon via OpenID - Implemented possibility to use embedded browser
  • 3645976 - AO: BIP - Logon User is not available when using OpenID authentication
  • 3667319 - AO scheduling issues after upgrading server add-on to 2.8.26/27

4. Content promotion

Next we will take a look on activities related to content migration.

4.1 Target System Server Configuration

  • Task: Adjust setting realted to the promotion execution.
  • Details:
  •  Required Running Services
    • Core Services (Must Run):
    • Central Management Server (CMS)
    • Input File Repository Server (FRS)
    • Output File Repository Server (FRS)
    • Adaptive Job Server (AJS) with increased heap
    • Adaptive Processing Server (APS) with LCM services
    • Crystal Reports Application Server (RAS)
    • Connection Server
  • Memory Configuration:
    • Configure Promotion Management Service APS heap size to handle large content imports - minimum 15GB for bulk migrations. Set Java heap parameters in CMC > Servers > APS Properties > Command Line Arguments: -javaargs -Xmx15g or higher 
    • Increase AJS heap size to minimum 15GB for large-scale promotions. Configure in CMC > Servers > AJS Properties > Command Line Arguments: -javaargs -Xmx15g
  • System Settings
    • Disable auditing on target system during migration
    • Disable monitoring in CMC > Monitoring Application
    • Disable Platform Search/indexing to improve performance
    • Configure adequate temporary space - minimum 2.5x FRS size
  • Turn OFF rollback on target server for large data imports to improve performance
  • Disable firewalls/antivirus temporarily during migration if possible 
  • Authentication Settings
    • Configure external authentication on target but do NOT import groups initially
    • Disable authentication temporarily during bulk user/group migration for better performance
    • Re-enable authentication after user migration completion

4.2 Promotion Tool Selection

In next step you need to decide which of two available for content promotion tools is more suitable for your landscape/team. You can select between Promotion Management Wizard (PMW) and Command Line Interface (CLI). The table below summarise the feature for these tools:

 
Feature
PMW (Promotion Management Wizard)CLI (Command Line Interface)
Tool TypeGUI-based promotion toolCommand-line based tool
User InterfaceGraphical wizard interface with step-by-step guidanceText-based commands requiring syntax knowledge
Ease of UseUser-friendly for non-technical usersRequires technical expertise and command knowledge
Automation CapabilityLimited automation, primarily manual wizard stepsHigh automation potential through scripting
Batch OperationsSupports batch promotion of multiple objectsExcellent for bulk operations and scripting
Error HandlingVisual error messages and guided troubleshootingDetailed error logs but requires interpretation
Learning CurveLow - intuitive wizard-driven processHigh - requires command syntax and parameter knowledge
SchedulingManual execution through GUICan be scheduled via system schedulers
LoggingBuilt-in logging with visual feedbackComprehensive command-line logging
Remote ExecutionRequires GUI access to serverCan be executed remotely via SSH/terminal
Scripting SupportNo native scripting capabilityFull scripting and automation support
PerformanceGood for small to medium promotionsBetter performance for large-scale operations

The choice ultimately depends on your team's technical capabilities, automation requirements, and the specific nature of your promotion scenarios. Many organizations benefit from using both tools for different use cases within their BI platform management strategy. For example, for large-scale migrations:

  1. Use PMW for initial bulk content migration (users, groups, dependencies)
  2. Switch to CLI for large content in public/favourite folders or delta promotions and ongoing maintenance
  3. Use CLI for promoting instances and objects created after initial migration

Check out the Promotion Management best practices SAP KBAs:

  • 2464908 - SAP BI Promotion Management Best Practices [LCM]
  • 1969259 - LCMCLI Best Practices - How to promote thousands of objects in BI Platform using command line?
  • KBA 2464908, 2531264 - Best Practices for Promotion Management Wizard (PMW)
  •  SAP BI Pattern Book on Promotion
  • 3663096 - How to promote object or folder security but not content using the PMW tool when performing bulk content migration?

4.3 Phased Promotion Approach

For large deployment would make sense to split whole promotion in multiple phases. Below you will find recommended sequins for such aproach.

Phase 1: Security and Users.

  • Migrate user groups and users without dependencies
  • Include user artifacts (Inboxes, Favorites Folders, Personal Categories)
  • Validate user authentication and group memberships

Phase 2: Dependencies

  • Migrate Access Levels, Applications, Business Views, Calendars, Connections
  • Migrate Universes (UNX only), Data Source References, Events

Phase 3: Content Migration

  • Migrate public folders and content
  • Use selective content promotion in chunks for large repositories
  • For bulk operations, use LCM CLI with multiple queries capability

Phase 4: Security Application (Optional)

  • Apply object security using PMW by selecting objects at folder hierarchy endpoints
  • Consider using CLI for security replication following KBA 3663096 patterns

5. Testing and Validation

  • Task: Perform technical and functional testing.
  • Details:
    • Perform compatibility test and verify the functionality of all migrated assets on the new platform to ensure they work as intended.
    • Performance Testing: Conduct load testing to evaluate the performance of the BI2025 system under typical and peak conditionsUser Acceptance Testing (UAT): Engage business users in testing to validate usability and functionality from an end-user perspective.

6. Training & Documentation

  • Task: Consider to organize the trainings for end users and update the documentation
  • Details:
    • User Training: Provide comprehensive training sessions for users to acquaint them with new features and interfaces in BI2025.
    • Updated Documentation: Create and distribute updated documentation reflecting changes and new functionalities in the BI2025 environment.

I tried to provide some initial guides for migration to BI2025. The tasks can vary based on landscape complexity and available resource but general approach stays the same. 

Please also consider to check SAP Premium Engagement: A service roadmap for SAC, S/4 Embedded Analytics, Business Objects and Planning  for some details on SAP‚Äôs Center of Expertise (COE) for Analytics, Planning, and Consolidation and how we helping around analytic topics.

entry.title: ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

ABAP Proxies are one of the most widely used integration technologies in SAP landscapes. For years, they have been central to PI/PO-based integrations. Now, with the availability of ABAP Proxy support in SAP Integration Suite, customers can extend this capability to the cloud, accelerating their migration from PI/PO to Integration Suite. This closes an important gap for organizations transitioning from SAP Process Integration (PI/PO) to SAP Integration Suite .

This blog provides a technical overview and step-by-step setup guide for enabling generation of ABAP Proxies with Integration Suite.

What Are ABAP Proxies?

  • ABAP Proxies are generated classes in the SAP ABAP system based on service interfaces defined in the Enterprise Service Repository (ESR).

  • They allow ABAP developers to call or expose services without dealing with low-level communication protocols.

  • Proxies are commonly used for synchronous/asynchronous service calls, typically via SOAP adapters in PI/PO.

Why ABAP Proxy Support in SAP Integration Suite Matters?

Until recently, ABAP proxies were heavily tied to on-premise PI/PO middleware. With many customers moving their integration  to the cloud, there was a strong demand for equivalent support in Integration Suite.

Key benefits of the new support include:

  • Cloud-first Enablement ‚Äì Seamlessly connect SAP backends to Integration Suite using proxies.
  • Reuse of Existing Investments ‚Äì No need to redesign all integration scenarios; existing service interfaces can still be leveraged.
  • Simplified Migration from PI/PO ‚Äì Reduces the complexity of moving from legacy middleware to cloud-based integration.
  • Standardized Integration ‚Äì Continue using ESR artifacts and ABAP proxies as standardized communication interfaces.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Integration Suite tenant is active.
  • Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite (HTTPS) is enabled.
  • Certificates (for mutual TLS if required) are exchanged.
  • Service interface meant for proxy generation must already be present/imported inside an Integration Package of the  SAP Integration Suite tenant
  • You've a user with the role  AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned.

Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite

For ABAP Proxy to Integration Suite, the standard practice is to configure an SM59 destination of type G.

SM59 Destination Configuration (Type G) :

Configuration Steps in SM59 (Type G)

Go to Transaction SM59

Choose HTTP Connections to External Server.

Create a new destination  or Open the existing Destination with name SAP_PROXY_ESR 

Technical Settings

  • Target Host: The host name of Integration Suite tenant(Navigate to BTP Cockpit  Instances and Subscriptions  < your instance for Service Process Integration Runtime with api Plan> View Credentials (in JSON format) and copy the url(without https://)  Note : Do not use the clientId and client secret from the Service Key instance

  • Service No.: 443 (for HTTPS).
  • Path Prefix: Enter the following : /rest/api/v1/workspace/sproxy 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Logon & Security

  • Choose Basic Authentication
  • Enter the credentials of the Technical user  with role AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned and created with Default Identity Provider
  • Security Options
    • Select SSL Active
    • Import CPI‚Äôs Server certificate into transaction STRUST (SSL Client ‚Üí Standard).
    • Assign it to the relevant SSL Client PSE so that HTTPS trust is established

  • Save the changes and Perform Connection Test. Successful Connection Test result in HTTP 200 Ok Response .

 

 

 

 

 

 

Procedure to Generate ABAP Proxy

  • Log into the SAP ABAP backend system (ECC or S/4HANA).
  • Run transaction SPROXY.
    • This transaction allows browsing and generating proxies from  Service Interfaces present in the Integration Suite tenant that is configured in SM59 destination(SAP_PROXY_ESR)
    • In the Enterprise Service Browser view, navigate to Source --> ESR --> SWCs  to see the list of Integration Packages that contain atleast one of the proxy relevant artifacts(Datatypes,(Fault)Message Types,Service Interfaces) are listed.
    • Locate the Integration Package containing the desired Service Interface (Inbound or Outbound).
    • Drill down to Service Provider or Service Consumer.(Namespaces -->Choose the desire namespace -->Object Types)
    • Choose the Inbound (server proxy) or Outbound (client proxy) interface.
    • Right-click the selected Service Provider or Consumer ‚Üí choose Generate.
    • Proxy Generation Wizard opens. Provide:
    • Prefix for ABAP Class Names (if needed).
    • Package assignment (should be a transportable package, not $TMP if moving to QA/Prod).
    • Transport request for recording the generated objects.
    • The system creates ABAP proxy classes:
      • Inbound Server Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class implementing the interface with predefined methods (developer writes business logic here).
      • Outbound Client Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class to call external services (system generates methods to call the remote service).
      • Supporting DDIC structures, types, and message interfaces are also generated.
      • Save and Activate the generated proxies

Use the  generated proxy class to implement the Business logic  in Transaction SE80 or SE24 .

Current Limitations in the SPROXY Navigation Tree :

  • Folders are not visible in the SPROXY navigation tree
  • Datatype enhancements are not listed.
  • Classifications and Matching Service Interface details will be missing in the Proxy Editor of the Service Interface
  • ...

Recommended view to be used - Enterprise Services Browser view.

Also please ensure to import the service interfaces and its dependants to the Integration Suite tenant from the PI/PO ESR system that was earlier configured in SM 59 destination to be able to retain the already generated proxies. Try maintaining SWCV  to Integration Package mapping i.e. Avoid importing objects from multiple SWCV's to one Integration Packages.. Avoid having objects with same name and namespace in multiple Integration Packages.

entry.title: Re: Error 7000 while installing Integration services (B1if)
entry.content:
I reinstalled mine from the package B1IF10P_19-20009683.ZIP from SAP Download Center. I also found when searching the notes the following from SAP AI: 

Generated Answer
When installing the SAP Business One Integration Framework (B1if), issues may arise such as the installation rolling back without any errors or logs, particularly on Windows Server 2019 or 2022. To address this, it is recommended to manually install VC++ 2010 (x86/x64) before proceeding with the B1if installation. If the installation wizard closes unexpectedly during the process, reinstalling the B1if may resolve the issue. SAP plans to release feature packages or patches to address these problems, which will be available based on their discretion and the complexity of the implementation.
 
This helped my installation by installing the VC++2010 x64 for my Windows 2022 server, and it went through. Hope that helps.

entry.title: crystal report build. need to shed some lights!
entry.content:
Hi, 

This is for SAP Crystal Reports

we have below two scenarios in the system:

case scenario 1- we have part number ABC-12345 in line no.1 in the purchase order, received in ABC-12345, vouchered ABC-12345, added freight charge in line no.2 in invoice entry, maintenance fee in line no.3. 

case scenario 2- we have part number ABC-54321 in line no.1, freight charge in line no.2 in the purchase order, received in ABC-12345 and freight charge, vouchered ABC-12345 and freight charge.

we want to capture the cost plus overheads such as freight charge and maintenance fee all together for ABC-12345. we created a report for it, outer join receiver line no. to payable line no., but when we filter parts starting with "ABC's", the report also filter out all the overheads...it looks like payable line no. should be outer join something but i can't think about any related tables to link with.

we currently have purc_order_id and line no. from pur_order_line outer join receiver_line's purc_order_id and purc_order_line_no; purc_order_id from receiver_line inner join payable_line, purc_order_id and purc_order_line_no from receiver_line outer join payable_line; voucher_id from payable inner join voucher_id of payable_line.

Thank you!! @Chuma

entry.title: External Serial Number DM x EWM integration
entry.content:
Dear colleagues/community members,
We hope you are well.

We are working on a crucial improvement for those who use the integration between SAP Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) and SAP Digital Manufacturing (DM): the need to support External Serial Numbers in the communication between the two systems.
Currently, this limitation directly impacts traceability and operational efficiency in manufacturing processes that rely on external serialization.
For SAP to prioritize the development of this functionality, we need to reach a significant number of votes on the SAP Customer Influence Portal.

How to help in 30 seconds:
Click the request link below: https://influence.sap.com/sap/ino/#/idea/356684/?section=sectionVotes
Log in with your S user (or P user).
Click the "Vote" button to support this improvement.

Thank you for taking a minute of your time to vote. Your vote is essential for the product's development.

Sincerely,

entry.title: Re: Help with Retrieving Modified Condition Values in IF_...
entry.content:
Check the following :

  • There is a UserExit / Enhancement Point in Prgr. "SAPLV69A" Include Prgr. "LV69AO03" with a routine "PERFORM FELDAUSWAHL" ...
  • The routine can be enhanced to do some custom Screen-modifications, but you could use the UserExit and / or Enhancement-Point to check the "KOMV" Structure and compare the (recently updated but nog yet committed) input to the Conditions in the DB ...

Hope this helps.

Kind regards

Nic T.

entry.title: What does "APF Buffers Found in Cache" (in sp_sysmon) mean?
entry.content:
In the sp_sysmon Asynchronous Prefetch Activity Report doc page it says:

"APF Buffers Found in Cache ‚Äì reports the number buffers from APF look-ahead sets that were found in the data cache during the sample interval. Asynchronous prefetch tries to find a page to read in the data cache using a quick scan, without holding the cache spinlock. If that does not succeed, APF then performs a thorough scan holding the spinlock"

What is an "APF look-ahead set"?

Is this saying the APF process will fetch some pages of data then check if they're already in the main cache?

If so, then if the "APF Buffers Found in Cache" number is high, does it mean the APF performed useless work?  (ie., fetched pages that were already cached?)

Stated another way, who does the "found" refer to?   Does "found" refer to APF process finding the buffers already in the main data cache? (bad)   Or does "found" refer to a user process finding the pages in the data cache as a result of the APF?  (good)

Thanks in advance
Ben

entry.title: How to integrate a middleware program into SAP or is it possible to upload the middleware to SAP
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I m supposed to make a mobile application that sends data to SAP tables. As far as I search it is possible to do with OData, Gateway and BAPI structures. 

I already made the mobile app, it sends data as a json file to a middleware program which written in node.js. The idea behind not sending data directly from app to SAP and using middleware is security issues and being sure that all datas are in the right type and right column to add.

As I said the mobil app is ready, it sends a json file to a middleware. The middleware is also ready, it converts datas in json file to corresponding fields of tables and will send them to Gateway. My priority is uploading that middleware to SAP system and run it from there if it is possible. If it is not then I have to upload it to another server I guess. Did anyone has experienced or heard a structure like that? Is it possible to upload a node.js middleware into SAP and run it directly from there?
